410.

Finally, Claimant submits that Respondent's reliance on international instruments other than the ECT, which contain language different from the ECT, is also unavailing. Claimant states that "the Respondent cannot rely on the language contained in irrelevant international instruments to provide for the additional requirements and exceptions that the Respondent now seeks to insert into the ECT."

**b) Tribunal's Decision**
--------------------------

411.

As noted earlier in the present Interim Award, according to Article 31 of the VCLT, a treaty must be interpreted first on the basis of its plain language. On its face, Article 1(7)(a)(ii) of the ECT contains no requirement other than that the claimant company be duly organized in accordance with the law applicable in a Contracting Party. The Tribunal agrees with Professor Crawford that in order to qualify as a protected Investor under Article 1(7) of the ECT, a company is merely required to be organized under the laws of a Contracting Party. As Professor Crawford rightly points out:

The Treaty imposes no further requirements with respect to shareholding, management, *siège social* or location of its business activities (...). Companies incorporated in Contracting Parties are embraced by the definition, regardless of the nationality of shareholders, the origin of investment capital or the nationality of directors or management.98

Professor James Crawford, SC, *Energy Charter Treaty Arbitration: Jurisdiction Issues,* 22 June 2006, para. 126.

412.

The Tribunal is not unmindful of Respondent's assertions concerning ownership and control of Claimant. The proper context in which to examine these assertions, however, is in the analysis of Article 17 of the Treaty, according to which ownership or control of a claiming party by citizens or nationals of a third State may, if certain other conditions are met, entitle a responding State to deny the benefits of Part III of the Treaty to the claiming party. The Tribunal will address Respondent's ownership and control argument in the next chapter of this Interim Award.

413.

Here, however, the Tribunal is dealing not with Article 17 but with Article 1(7). The Tribunal is bound to interpret the terms of the ECT, including Article 1(7), not as they might have been written but as they were actually written. Article 1(7) is more comprehensively and neutrally cast than, for example, Article 21 of the ILC Draft Articles on International Responsibility of the State for Injuries Caused in its Territory to the Person or Property of Aliens. Article 1(7) provides that, "Investor" means:

(a) with respect to a Contracting Party:

[...]

(ii) a company or other organization organized in accordance with the law applicable in that Contracting Party;

Claimant was organized "in accordance with the law applicable" in a Contracting Party. Claimant accordingly qualifies as a company so organized in the instant case. The Tribunal is not entitled, by the terms of the ECT, to find otherwise.

414.

In so concluding, the Tribunal follows the holding of the Partial Award in *Saluka Investments BV (The Netherlands) v. The Czech Republic,* of 17 March 2006. That tribunal, of which the late Sir Arthur Watts was the distinguished chairman, held:

240. The Tribunal has some sympathy for the argument that a company which has no real connection with a State party to a BIT, and which is in reality a mere shell company controlled by another company which is not constituted under the laws of that State, should not be entitled to invoke the provisions of that treaty. Such a possibility lends itself to abuses of the arbitral procedure, and to practices of 'treaty-shopping' which can share many of the disadvantages of the widely criticized practice of 'forum shopping'.

241. However that may be, the predominant factor which must guide the Tribunal's exercise of its functions is the terms in which the parties to the Treaty now in question have agreed to establish the Tribunal's jurisdiction. In the present context, that means the terms in which they have agreed upon who is an investor who may become a claimant entitled to invoke the Treaty's arbitration procedures. The parties had complete freedom of choice in this matter, and they chose to limit entitled 'investors' to those satisfying the definition set out in Article 1 of the Treaty. The Tribunal cannot in effect impose upon the parties a definition of 'investor' other than that which they themselves agreed. That agreed definition required only that the claimant-investor should be constituted under the laws of (in the present case) The Netherlands, and it is not open to the Tribunal to add other requirements which the parties could themselves have added but which they omitted to add.99

*See also Petrobart Limited v. The Kyrgyz Republic*, Arbitration No. 126/2003, Arbitration Institute of the Stockholm Chamber of Commerce, Award of 29 March 2005, available on http://ita.law.uvic.ca.

415.

The Tribunal knows of no general principles of international law that would require investigating how a company or another organization operates when the applicable treaty simply requires it to be organized in accordance with the laws of a Contracting Party. The principles of international law, which have an unquestionable importance in treaty interpretation, do not allow an arbitral tribunal to write new, additional requirements— which the drafters did not include—into a treaty, no matter how auspicious or appropriate they may appear.100

*See* *Acquisition of Polish Nationality*, Advisory Opinion (1923), PCIJ ser. B, No. 7, p. 20 ("To impose an additional condition for the acquisition of Polish nationality, a condition not provided for in the Treaty..., would be equivalent not to interpreting the Treaty, but to reconstructing it.") Exhibit C-144. Respondent argues, in the alternative, that the general rules and principles of international law are an integral part of Russian domestic law, pursuant to Article 15(4) of the Constitution, and that an interpretation of Article 1(7) of the Treaty that "dispense[d]" with such rules would therefore be inconsistent with Russian law, triggering the inconsistency clause of Article 45(1) of the Treaty. The Tribunal cannot accept this argument, however, in light of its decision on the proper interpretation of Article 45(1) (*See* Chapter A, above.)

416.

Indeed, in similar circumstances, other arbitral tribunals have held the opposite: they have emphasized that the reference to the State of incorporation is the most common method of defining the nationality of a company and that, in any event, once a treaty makes that choice in specific and unambiguous terms, any other method of assessing the company's nationality is ruled out.101 Specifically with regard to Article 1(7) of the ECT, the arbitral tribunal held in the case of *Plama v. Bulgaria* that to qualify as an investor it was sufficient for a company to be organized in accordance with the law applicable in Cyprus, irrespective of who might own or control the Investor.102

*See Tokios Tokelés v. Ukraine*, ICSID Case No. ARB/02/18, Decision on Jurisdiction of 29 April 2004, *available at* http://icsid.worldbank.org, paras. 28-29 (with a dissenting opinion by Prosper Weil).

*Plama Consortium Limited v. Republic of Bulgaria*, ICSID Case No. ARB/03/24, Decision on Jurisdiction of 8 February 2005, (2005) 20:1 *ICSID Review* 262, para. 128.

417.

The Tribunal accordingly holds that Claimant, being a company organized in accordance with the laws of the Republic of Cyprus, qualifies as an Investor for the purposes of Article 1(7)(a)(ii) of the ECT.

**3. Does Claimant "Own or Control" a Protected "Investment" under Article 1(6)?**
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

418.

In Article 1(6) of the Treaty, "Investment" is defined to mean:

[...] every kind of asset, owned or controlled directly or indirectly by an Investor and includes:

(a) tangible and intangible, and movable and immovable, property, and any property rights such as leases, mortgages, liens and pledges;

(b) a company or business enterprise, or shares, stock, or other forms of equity participation in a company or business enterprise, and bonds and other debt of a company or business enterprise;

(c) claims to money and claims to performance pursuant to contract having an economic value and associated with an Investment;

(d) Intellectual Property;

(e) Returns;

(f) any right conferred by law or contract or by virtue of any licences and permits granted pursuant to law to undertake any Economic Activity in the Energy Sector.

[...]

419.

At issue in this section of the Interim Award is whether, as alleged by Claimant, Claimant owns 223,699,175 shares (or 10 percent) of Yukos and if so, whether such Yukos shares qualify as an "Investment" for purposes of Article 1(6) of the Treaty.

420.

Before turning to the Parties' submissions on each of these issues, the Tribunal sets out below the key elements of the relevant factual background, based on the uncontested documentary evidence in the record:

a) From the date of its incorporation (7 February 2001) until 25 April 2001, Claimant was wholly-owned by YUL.

b) On 25 April 2001, YUL, as Settlor, and WJB Chiltern Trust Company (Jersey) Limited ("**Chiltern**"), as Custodian Trustee, established the VP Trust under the laws of Jersey.103

c) By a separate instrument of transfer dated 25 April 2001, YUL transferred all of its shares (*i.e.*, 100 percent) of Claimant to Chiltern.104

d) By a separate deed of transfer, also dated 25 April 2001, YUL transferred to Chiltern 223,699,175 shares of Yukos, representing 10 percent of the issued share capital of Yukos (defined in the VP Trust as the "**Russian Shares**" and referred to herein as either the Russian Shares or the "**Yukos Shares**").105

e) On 26 April 2001, Chiltern became the registered owner of all of the shares of Claimant that had been transferred by YUL to Chiltern the day before (defined in the VP Trust as the "**Cypriot Shares**," and referred to herein as either the Cypriot Shares or the "**VPL Shares**").106

f) As mentioned, the Russian Shares were initially transferred to Chiltern upon constitution of the VP Trust. At the same time, the VP Trust expressly contemplates the Russian Shares being owned by Claimant either directly as a "company which is owned by the Custodian Trustee,"107 since Claimant was owned by Chiltern as of 25 April 2001, or "as nominee of the Custodian Trustee."108

g) The VP Trust states in its recitals that Yukos has established in Russia a program to be known as the Veteran Social Support Program (the "**Program**") to provide subsidy and assistance to employees who wish to relocate upon termination of their employment with Yukos, and that "a portion of the proceeds of sale of the [Yukos Shares] is to be transferred to the Russian Service Provider for donation to certain participants in the Program."109

h) Consistent with the statements in the recitals, Clause 3(2) of the VP Trust provides that the Russian Shares are to be sold by Chiltern (or by Claimant, through operation of Clause 6(3) or Clause 6(6) of the VP Trust) on instructions from the Russian Service Provider ("**RSP**").

i) Clause 3(3) of the VP Trust provides for the proceeds of the sale of the Russian Shares to be divided into three tranches, as follows:

(a) to pay to the Settlor [*i.e.*, YUL] the Basic Sum (being a sum equal to the lesser of the Gross Consideration [*i.e.* the gross proceeds of the sale of each Yukos share] and the sum of US$1.20) less the costs of the sale of the Russian Share and related expenses;

(b) to pay to the RSP the Mezzanine Amount (being a sum equal to the difference between the Basic Sum and the lower of the Gross Consideration and the sum of US$3.25);

(c) to pay to the Settlor [*i.e.*, YUL] the balance of the Gross Consideration.

j) Clause 4 of the VP Trust provides that any income arising on the Russian Shares prior to any such sale and other than the proceeds of such sale shall be paid to the Settlor (*i.e.*, YUL)

k) Clause 5(1) of the VP Trust provides that Chiltern (or Claimant, through operation of Clause 6(3) or Clause 6(6) of the VP Trust) shall exercise any voting rights attaching to the Russian Shares pursuant to "Voting Instruction" received from a "Voting Committee" as set forth in Clause 9.

l) Clause 9(3) of the VP Trust explains that the Voting Committee shall be composed of four members, with YUL, the Central Commission of the Veteran Social Support Program and the Board of Directors of Yukos appointing one member each and a fourth member, with a casting vote, appointed by unanimous consent of the first three.

m) Pursuant to the "Rules and Regulations of the Voting Committee of the Veteran Petroleum Trust,"110 the objectives in determining the voting instructions for the Yukos Shares are as follows, in descending order of priority:

(1) Maximize the value of the [Yukos] shares in order to achieve the full realization of the Mezzanine Amount [...] which will be used to fund the Veteran Social Support Program for the employees of OAO NK Yukos

(2) Maximize the value of the Gross Consideration [...]

n) Pursuant to an Agreement between the RSP and Yukos dated 11 May 2001 ("**RSP Agency Agreement**"),111 the Mezzanine Amount is to be distributed by the RSP directly to the retiring Yukos veteran employees included in a regularly updated list provided to the RSP by Yukos.

o) On 8 October 2007, the VP Trust was amended112 to introduce a new definition of the RSP and to take into account the fact that (i) Yukos went into liquidation on 1 August 2006 and (ii) VPL had commenced an arbitration claim against the Russian Federation under the Energy Charter Treaty (*i.e.*, the present arbitration). The amendment provides that any amount recovered in respect of this arbitration (whether in the form of an award or a settlement) shall be treated as the Gross Consideration on a sale of the Yukos Shares, and disposed of in accordance with Clause 3(3) of the VP Trust. The amendment provides further that the RSP "shall apply the Mezzanine Amount in accordance with the Program or in such other manner as it may in its absolute discretion think fit for the benefit of all or any one or more of the employees and former employees of Yukos and their respective spouses and former spouses children and remoter issue and dependants." Finally, the amendment modified the composition of the Voting Committee from four members to three members, with YUL and the Board of Directors of VPL each appointing one member, and the third member, with a casting vote, selected unanimously by the first two members.

**(ii) Interpretation of Article 1(6) and the Relevance of Beneficial Ownership and Control of the Yukos Shares**
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

433.

Respondent maintains that, even if Claimant has nominal legal ownership of the Yukos Shares, it does not have beneficial ownership or control of the Yukos Shares. Respondent argues that this is material since nominal legal ownership of an asset is insufficient to establish ownership of an "Investment" under the Treaty:

In the absence of a specific Treaty provision defining the quality of ownership and control, the quality of ownership and control needs to be determined pursuant to the applicable rules and principles of international law. In addition, under the rules of treaty interpretation, Article1(6) of the Treaty itself needs to be interpreted in accordance with general international law.118

On the basis of this premise, Respondent asserts that:

General international law ignores nominal or record ownership in favour of real or beneficial ownership in order to determine the nationality of a claim.119

Respondent's First Memorial, para. 86.

*Ibid*. at para. 87.

434.

In response, Claimant submits that, as for purposes of determining whether it qualifies as an "Investor" under Article 1(7) of the Treaty, the determination of whether Claimant holds a qualified "Investment" must begin with an examination of the language of the ECT. Considering the express terms of Article 1(6) of the Treaty, Claimant asserts that it holds a qualified "Investment" because it owns the Yukos Shares and has done so at all relevant times for purposes of this arbitration.

435.

Claimant argues that nothing in the language of the ECT requires a showing of anything more than legal ownership to establish a qualified "Investment." Claimant contends that it is sufficient to show that it owns or controls the asset in question, other purported requirements being "superfluous and unnecessary" once ownership is established. As for the type of ownership required, Claimant asserts that there is no basis for Respondent's argument that beneficial ownership is necessary. Claimant argues that this is contrary to the plain language of the ECT, which provides for a very broad, simple definition of "Investment" that includes legal ownership.

436.

In other words, Claimant argues that Respondent's assertion that Claimant does not "beneficially own" or "control" the Yukos Shares is irrelevant for purposes of determining this Tribunal's jurisdiction because even if it were true, it does not negate Claimant's direct legal ownership of the Yukos Shares.

--------------------------------------------------------------

***(1) The Power to Vote the Yukos Shares***
--------------------------------------------

Respondent notes that the power to vote the Yukos Shares thus rests with the Voting Committee, which, Respondent argues, is controlled by YUL and thus Yukos interests, and "dominated ultimately by Khodorkovsky/Lebedev."120

The legal relationship between the RSP and Yukos is set out in the RSP Agency Agreement.

63 Or to exercise its voting and other powers over VPL, so as to procure that VPL sell (given that VPL holds the Yukos Shares).

64 Or by VPL under clause 6(3) of the Trust to be.

65 Or is by VPL under clause 6(3) of the Trust.

Mr. Green adds the following points on the issue of control of the Yukos shares:

145. Nor does it seem to me that the fact that the RSP may in the future direct a sale of the Yukos Shares mean that the RSP in the present "controls" the Yukos Shares.

[...]

147. ***(3) Beneficial Interest in the Income and Sale Proceeds from the Yukos Shares***
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

448.

Clause 3(3) of the VP Trust provides that, upon the sale of the Yukos Shares, as directed by the RSP, the proceeds of such sale are to be divided into three tranches. The first tranche (the Basic Sum) is paid to YUL, as the Settlor. The next tranche—the Mezzanine Amount—is to be paid to the RSP (as agent for Yukos), for distribution to veteran employees of Yukos in accordance with the Program. The final and third tranche (any balance of the proceeds of the sale) is again to be paid to YUL, as the Settlor. Moreover, Clause 4 of the VP Trust provides that any income arising on the Yukos Shares (*e.g.*, dividends) prior to sale in accordance with the VP Trust is to be paid to YUL, as the Settlor.

449.

On the basis of these provisions, Respondent argues that, on a true construction of the VP Trust, the only beneficiaries of the trust are YUL (which receives income from the Yukos Shares, and both the Basic Sum and any balance of the Gross Consideration upon a sale of the Yukos Shares directed by the RSP) and Yukos (which, through the agency of the RSP, receives any Mezzanine Amount upon a sale of the Yukos Shares directed by the RSP).

450.

In his First Opinion, Mr. Mann describes the operation of the VP Trust as follows:

11. The trust deed can be summarised as providing for the transfer of the Cypriot shares and the Russian shares to Chiltern as custodian trustee (clause 2) on defined trusts for YUL and YUKOS (clause 3).

12. The defined trust of the Russian shares (clause 3) is a trust for sale (clauses 3(2) and 11(2)(c) and (d)). The trigger for sale is to be a written direction given by an entity to be appointed by YUKOS, defined as the Russian Service Provider ("the RSP"). In the meantime, the Russian shares are only voted in accordance with a "Voting instruction" (clause 5(1)) to be given by a "Voting Committee", whose members are to be one person appointed by YUL, one person appointed by the Central Commission of the Program, one person appointed by the board of YUKOS and a fourth person who is to be selected unanimously by the first three (clause 9). The proceedings of the Voting Committee are governed by 'Rules and Regulations' incorporated in a separate document. These consist of rudimentary procedural rules plus a mission statement, a "*mission*", stated as, "*to determine and deliver to [Chiltern] voting instructions for the shares in [the VPT]*", and "*objectives*", stated as (in so far as material), *"to maximise the value of the shares,"* which I take to mean Russian shares, *"in order to achieve the full realization of the Mezzanine Amount (as such term is defined in [the VPT] which will be used to fund [the Program]...*", and to, "*maximize the value of the Gross Consideration (as such term is defined in [the VPT])*". The trusts of the proceeds of sale in the VPT are (again in so far as material) to pay a portion defined as the "*Mezzanine Amount*" to the RSP and the balance to YUL, irrespective of whether the sale is pursuant to a direction given by the RSP or on termination of the trust (clause 3(3) and clause 11(2)). It is observable that the RSP is not a party to the VPT and that neither it nor YUKOS are expressed to hold the Mezzanine Amount on trust, whether on the trusts (if any) of the Program, or any other trust. And, crucially, Clause 1 of the VPT states that the RSP is the agent of YUKOS.

13. It follows that under the VPT Chiltern is to hold the Russian shares until sale and any proceeds of sale of the Russian shares which it receives following sale on trust for YUL and YUKOS absolutely according to their respective entitlements.

[emphasis added]

451.

Notably, Mr. Mann opines that the Mezzanine Amount effectively belongs to Yukos, since neither Yukos nor the RSP (as Yukos' agent) holds the Mezzanine Amount on trust for the veteran employees of Yukos that are allegedly supposed to benefit under the Program.

452.

In paragraph 18 of his First Opinion, Mr. Mann summarizes what he considers to be "the significant legal consequences" of the VP Trust in respect of beneficial ownership and control of the Yukos Shares. According to Mr. Mann, these are:

(1) YUL and YUKOS have concurrent beneficial interests in the Russian shares, YUL in the income (clause 4) and both of them in the proceeds of sale (clause 3);

(2) YUL and YUKOS can jointly instruct Chiltern to vote and/or re-transfer the Russian shares at their direction. Chiltern must comply because YUL and YUKOS are the beneficial owners as regards Chiltern. Chiltern cannot refuse. Chiltern, although a custodian trustee, is little more than a mere nominee.

453.

In order to reach his second conclusion, namely that YUL and Yukos control Chiltern's (or Claimant's) nominal ownership of the Yukos Shares to the point of being able to have those shares returned to them at their discretion, Mr. Mann relies on the principle of trust law referred to as the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier*. Mr. Mann explains the rule as follows:

Beneficiaries can, if *sui juris*, and [if] they are together entitled to the whole beneficial interest, put an end to the trust and direct the trustees to hand over the trust property as they direct. This is often referred to as the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier* (1841) 4 Beav. 115.

454.

Mr. Mann therefore concludes that neither Claimant nor Chiltern is the beneficial owner of the Yukos Shares, and that neither of them is in control of these shares.

455.

In response, Claimant refers to the following points made by its expert, Mr. Green:

• The VP Trust is an example of the kind of trust instrument which, as at 2001, might have been expected to be used in an offshore jurisdiction to establish an employee benefit scheme for the benefit of employees of a company based in another jurisdiction and is uncontroversial (Mr. Green notes that such arrangements are referred to in UK legal parlance as "unapproved profit sharing schemes" and are perfectly admissible).

• Based on a proper construction of the VP Trust, the veteran employees of Yukos who are meant to benefit from the Mezzanine Amount derived from the sale of the Yukos Shares are the beneficiaries of the trust, not Yukos itself.

• It is incorrect to assume that Yukos was intended to be the absolute beneficial owner of the Mezzanine Amount simply because the RSP is referred to as Yukos' agent in relation to the Program in the recitals of the VP Trust. The RSP—as is made very clear by the terms of the RSP Agency Agreement—is a mere conduit for the payment of proceeds from the sale of the Yukos Shares directly into the bank accounts of the retired Yukos employees.

456.

In relation to the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier*, Mr. Green opines that it is not available in the context of the trust over the Yukos Shares because, on what he considers to be the proper interpretation of the trust, the Yukos employees constitute an open beneficiary class. In any event, it is Mr. Green's opinion that, until the principle is actually invoked by the beneficiaries who would be entitled to invoke it, the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier* cannot justify the conclusion that YUL and Yukos "own" or "control" the Yukos Shares.

***(4) Validity of the Settlement into the VP Trust of the Mezzanine Amount***
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

457.

In his Second Opinion, Mr. Mann raises a new argument in relation to the Mezzanine Amount. He argues that the VP Trust was never effectively constituted in relation to the Yukos Shares. Specifically, he asserts that the trust purported to be established for the Mezzanine Amount is invalid as being in relation to a future expectancy. He opines as follows:

2.1 A useful starting point is in fact Mr. Green QC's ¶87 in which he accurately opines,

"*YUL has retained to itself all interest in the fruits of the YUKOS Shares with the exception of the Mezzanine Amount*".

He falls into error, however, in the next sentence,

"*It is only the Mezzanine Amount which has been settled for the benefit of employees within the contemplation of the Program in the present case*".

The reason is that the Mezzanine Amount, using his parlance, is but a possible future fruit of a chose in action (the Russian shares) which might or might not materialise. What has happened is that there has been an attempt to settle a future interest, termed in English law an 'expectancy', which under English law the court will only enforce if the intended transfer is a transfer for value. This was clearly not the case with the VPT, as Mr. Green QC appears to agree. Therefore, whichever way one views the VPT, there is not and has never been a fully constituted enforceable trust of the Mezzanine Amount.

[...]

2.3 As I would fully expect the Royal Court of Jersey to follow English law in this respect, it necessarily follows that YUL's attempt to settle the Mezzanine Amount was entirely nugatory.

[emphasis added]

458.

Having concluded that the trust as applied to the Mezzanine Amount was unenforceable, Mr. Mann, in his Second Opinion, argues for a somewhat different application of the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier*. He sets out his argument as follows:

3.3 In the present case, we have a situation in which only the Mezzanine Amount is theoretically given to another (for this purpose it does not matter whether arguably either for YUL, YUKOS or the beneficiaries under the '*program*'), where the realization of this amount is both contingent and the right to receive it unenforceable (see C ¶¶2.1-2.3 above) and where the subject matter of the gift to Chiltern is Russian shares the income of which until sale is receivable only by YUL. This is a classic case, therefore, for the application of the doctrine [of *Saunders v. Vautier*] because there are no others with enforceable rights to the Russian shares and fruits besides YUL.

3.4 I should observe before turning briefly to Mr. Green QC's other theories that Mr. Green QC opines (¶¶40 and 41) that the trust continues irrespective of the doctrine until a valid request for the re-transfer of the Russian shares has been fully executed and therefore that neither YUL nor YUKOS could exercise control in the meantime. This is theoretically correct but YUL could require Chiltern to cause VPL to re-transfer the Russian shares at any time and, in my opinion, obtain an order from the Royal Court compelling Chiltern so to do. Chiltern's 'control' is thus seen to be truly illusory.

459.

In his Second Opinion, Mr. Green disagrees with Mr. Mann's new argument, both in respect of the validity of the trust as it relates to the Mezzanine Amount and in respect of the application of the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier*. He opines that the VP Trust was completely and effectively constituted since YUL, being the owner of present property (the Yukos Shares), was able to assign such present property to a trustee (Chiltern) to hold the same on what are otherwise conceptually certain trusts. In Mr. Green's view, the Mezzanine Amount will be paid into the Program on sale of the Yukos Shares or on termination of the VP Trust and whether or not it translates into actual money does not make it a mere expectancy. Mr. Green argues that the cases concerning assignments of future property or expectancies therefore have absolutely nothing to do with the VP Trust.

460.

Mr. Green also reiterates his previously expressed opinion that the application of the rule in *Saunders v*. *Vautier* cannot lead to the conclusion that the Yukos Shares are "owned or controlled" by YUL and/or Yukos.

**(iv) Injection of Foreign Capital as a Requirement for a Qualifying "Investment" under Article 1(6) of the Treaty**
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

461.

Finally, Respondent asserts that Claimant's nominal ownership of the Yukos Shares does not qualify as an "Investment" because no injection of foreign capital into the Russian Federation took place as a result of the acquisition of the shares. Respondent submits that Russian law requires that a foreign investment be acquired with capital of foreign origin, and that Respondent can invoke Russian law requirements in connection with the interpretation of Article 1(6) of the Treaty by operation of the inconsistency clause of Article 45(1).

462.

Drawing support from the expansive definition of "Investment," Claimant asserts that "how the Claimant acquired its Yukos shares—including the 'origin of capital', whether it made an 'injection' of 'foreign capital', and whether it paid for the shares with cash or some other consideration—has no bearing on the Tribunal's determination whether Claimant holds a qualified 'Investment.'" Claimant argues that no authority exists to support Respondent's argument with respect to the necessity for injection of foreign capital and cites the decision in *Tokios Tokelės v. Ukraine* in support of its position.

463.

Claimant also points to various public statements by then President Vladimir Putin in which he stressed that "repatriation" or "return" of Russian capital from countries like Germany and Cyprus was "a very good sign" and "a good signal."121

President Vladimir Putin, Speech at the Energy Conference, London, 26 June 2003, *available at* the President of Russia's official website at http://www.kremlin.ru, Annex C-1437. President Vladimir Putin, Answers to Questions from the Participants in the Business Meeting of the APEC Members, Shanghai, 19 October 2001, *available at* http://www.kremlin.ru, Annex C-1436.

464.

Finally, although insisting that it is not required by the ECT and not relevant therefore to the issue of jurisdiction, Claimant asserts, by reference to the transactions through which the VP Trust was established, that it did in fact legally acquire the Yukos Shares in 2001.

**b) Tribunal's Decision**
--------------------------

465.

The Tribunal's decision will proceed in accordance with the same subheadings used in the previous section.

**(i) Claimant's Legal Title to the Yukos Shares**
--------------------------------------------------

466.

As noted earlier, Respondent's first and principal argument is that Claimant has failed to establish that Claimant itself, as opposed to Chiltern, actually acquired legal title to the Yukos Shares. For the following reasons, the Tribunal cannot accept Respondent's argument.

467.

First, the VP Trust itself provides the following at Clause 6(3):

the provisions of this agreement relating to the Shares [that is, both the Yukos Shares and the VPL Shares] shall also apply mutatis mutandis in respect of Shares which are not owned by the Custodian Trustee but are owned by a company or a subsidiary of any company which is owned by the Custodian Trustee.122

Annex C-1163.

468.

The Tribunal agrees with Claimant that this very specific language in the deed of trust itself strongly suggests that it was the intention of YUL, as Settlor, and Chiltern, as Custodian Trustee, to transfer the Yukos Shares into Claimant's ownership once YUL's 100 percent interest in Claimant was itself transferred to Chiltern. Indeed, given the transactions that were concluded as part of the constitution of the VP Trust, namely the simultaneous transfer to Chiltern of a 100 percent interest in Claimant and of a 10 percent interest in Yukos, it was Claimant (and Claimant only) that qualified as "a company owned by the Custodian Trustee," leaving the 10 percent interest in Yukos (and only this asset) to qualify as "Shares which are not owned by the Custodian Trustee but are owned by a company [i.e., Claimant]... which is owned by the Custodian Trustee."

469.

Second, the language in the Mourant opinion letter dated 28 June 2006 that Respondent invokes against Claimant only makes clear that Chiltern holds both the VPL Shares and the Yukos Shares on trust for the Settlor of the VP Trust. This language is not inconsistent with ownership of the Yukos Shares by Claimant since, pursuant to Clause 6(3) of the VP Trust, and as confirmed by Mr. Green, whose evidence the Tribunal accepts on this point, "the trusts as they affect the Yukos Shares apply equally as regards such shares where they are held by a company owned by Chiltern (i.e., VPL) as they would do if the Yukos Shares were held directly by Chiltern" [emphasis added].123

Mr. Brian Green, QC, *Opinion re the Veteran Petroleum Trust*, 4 May 2007, note 11.

470.

Third, Respondent's argument that Claimant does not own the Yukos Shares because its legal title to those shares vested on 26 April 2001, after they had already been transferred to Chiltern by YUL on 25 April, is contradicted by the bank account statements in the record. Notwithstanding Respondent's attempt to impugn these records, the Tribunal is satisfied that the bank account statements constitute reliable evidence.

471.

Annex C-1177 shows the Yukos Shares being credited to the VPL account with UBS on 26 April 2001. On 21 June 2001, the Yukos shares were transferred to UBS AG—that is UBS Zurich—and Annex C-1179 shows the shares held on the VPL account with UBS Zurich as of 30 June 2001. The bank records are also available for 30 September 2001, 31 December 2001, 31 March 2002, 30 June 2002, 30 September 2002, 31 December 2002, 31 March 2003, 30 June 2003, 31 October 2003, 31 December 2003, 31 March 2004, and 30 June 2004. Annex C-1180 then contains similar statements for the UBS account in London. These records demonstrate that, as of 30 September 2004, VPL, which is the holder of the account, owns the 223,699,175 Yukos shares. The same is true as of 31 December 2004, 31 March 2005, 30 June 2005 and so on. The Tribunal considers these bank statements to be compelling evidence of ownership.

472.

Fourth, even assuming that the Yukos Shares were "owned" by Chiltern as of 25 April 2001 and therefore not "validly" transferred by YUL to VPL on 26 April 2001, Chiltern, which held the VPL Shares and the Yukos Shares as trustee, clearly ratified the arrangement and carried on for several years as if VPL was indeed the owner of the Yukos Shares, by knowing and indeed controlling the corporate entity on whose account with UBS in Zurich and London the Yukos Shares were deposited. The Tribunal finds apt the following language used by Mr. Green to describe the situation: "the apparent purpose of Chiltern holding the VPL Shares is closely connected with its holding the Yukos Shares (which as noted Chiltern has caused or permitted YUL to vest in VPL)" [emphasis added].

473.

While the Swiss Federal Tribunal, in a recent decision, was only called upon to determine whether Chiltern and VPL had standing to appeal or not, the Tribunal cannot ignore its decision of 10 June 2004 (Annex C-302), which comforts its present finding:

VP [*i.e.*, VPL] est une société de Chypre dont le capital est entièrement détenu par Yukos. Celle-ci exploite plusieurs gisements pétrolifères dans des régions inhospitalières de la Russie (notamment le Grand Nord). Afin d'assurer à ses employés la possibilité de se réinstaller après leur retraite dans d'autres régions de Russie, YUKOS a mis sur pied en 1999 et 2000, un projet intitulé « Yukos Veteran Program »: Celui-ci a consisté à transférer environ 10% du capital social de Yukos à VP. Les bénéficiaires, soit les personnes ayant travaillé au moins dix ans au service de Yukos à compter du 1er janvier 1999 et dont la demande a été agréée, reçoivent le produit de la vente d'une part déterminée des actions de Yukos.

WJB [*i.e.*, Chiltern] est une société des Iles Anglo-Normandes. Le 25 avril 2001, Yukos a passé un accord (Appointment of Custodian Trustee) avec WJB, en confiant à celle-ci comme « Trustee » le mandat de gérer les fonds codés à VP, selon des modalités et des procédures définies.

[emphasis added]

*Tribunal's translation:*

*VPL is a Cyprus company the capital of which is entirely held by Yukos. The latter exploits several oil wells in some inhospitable areas of Russia (particularly in the North). In order to ensure for its employees the possibility to resettle in other regions of Russia after their retirement, YUKOS set up in 1999 and 2000 a project entitled "Yukos Veteran Program". That consisted in transferring about 10 % of the capital of Yukos to VPL. The beneficiaries, namely the people having worked at least ten years in Yukos' service as from 1 January 1999 and whose request was accepted, receive a determined share of the sale of the Yukos shares.*

*Chiltern is a company of the Channel Islands. On 25 April 2001, Yukos entered into an agreement (Appointment of Custodian Trustee') with Chiltern, entrusting to the former as "Trustee" the mandate to manage the funds entrusted to VP according to some defined procedures and modalities.*

[emphasis added]

474.

For all of these reasons, the Tribunal concludes that Claimant has satisfied its burden of proof and demonstrated that it has legal title to the Yukos Shares.

475.

Nor can the Tribunal accept Respondent's argument based on alleged gaps in ownership of the Yukos Shares by Claimant during certain periods. The record shows that the Yukos shares held by Claimant were transferred to its account with UBS London in August 2004.124 Before then, as of 26 April 2001, they were consistently held on Claimant's bank account with Brunswick UBS Nominees in Moscow125 or with UBS Zurich.126

*See* Annex C-1180 and Annex C-195.

*See* Annex C-1177.

*See* Annex C-1179.

**(ii) Interpretation of Article 1(6) and Relevance of Beneficial Ownership and Control of the Yukos Shares**
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

476.

Having established that Claimant has valid legal title to the Yukos Shares, the Tribunal now turns to the interpretation of Article 1(6) of the Treaty and, specifically, to whether nominal legal ownership of an asset by an "Investor" is sufficient to establish ownership of an "Investment" under Article 1(6) or whether either beneficial ownership or control is required.

477.

The Tribunal finds that the ECT, by its terms, applies to an "Investment" owned nominally by a qualifying "Investor," and that nothing more is required. Respondent's submission that simple legal ownership of shares does not qualify as an Investment under Article 1(6)(b) of the ECT finds no support in the text of the Treaty. The breadth of the definition of Investment in the ECT is emphasized by many eminent legal scholars.127 As defined in Article 1(6) of the ECT, an "Investment" includes "every kind of asset" owned *or* controlled, directly or indirectly, and extends not only to shares of a company but to its debt (Article 1(6)(b) of the ECT), to monetary claims and contractual performance as well as "any right conferred by law" (Article 1(6)(f) of the ECT, emphasis added). The Tribunal recalls again that, according to Article 31 of the VCLT, a treaty is to be interpreted in good faith in accordance with the ordinary meaning of its terms. The Tribunal reads Article 1(6)(b) of the ECT as containing the widest possible definition of an interest in a company, including shares (as in the case at hand), with no indication whatsoever that the drafters of the Treaty intended to limit ownership to "beneficial" ownership.

*See* Craig Bamberger, "An Overview of the Energy Charter Treaty," pp. 8-9, *in* Thomas Wälde (ed.), *The Energy Charter Treaty: An East-West Gateway for Investment and Trade* (1996); Thomas Wälde, "International Investment under the 1994 Energy Charter Treaty," pp. 271-273, *in* Thomas Wälde (ed.), *The Energy Charter Treaty: An East-West Gateway for Investment and Trade* (1996); Esa Paasivirta, "The Energy Charter Treaty and Investment Contracts: Towards Security of Contracts," pp. 356-358, *in* Thomas Wälde (ed.), *The Energy Charter Treaty: An East-West Gateway for Investment and Trade* (1996).

**(iii) Beneficial Ownership and Control of the Yukos Shares under the VP Trust**
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

478.

In light of the Tribunal's interpretation of Article 1(6) of the Treaty, and its finding that Claimant has valid legal title to the Yukos shares, the Tribunal need not, strictly speaking, decide the issues of beneficial ownership or control. For sake of completeness, however, the Tribunal sets out below its views on these questions.

479.

The Tribunal sees no reason to depart from the pertinent and convincing analysis set forth by Mr. Green in his two opinions. In short, while Mr. Green conceded that Claimant does not control the Yukos Shares (since Voting Instructions for voting the Yukos Shares come from the Voting Committee), he provided persuasive evidence that none of the elements of the VP Trust undermine Claimant's ownership of the Yukos Shares

480.

Thus, in relation to the Mezzanine Amount, the Tribunal finds as follows in relation to Respondent's first argument, which was based on Mr. Mann's First Opinion:

• The beneficiary of the Mezzanine Amount is not Yukos or its agent, the RSP. Rather, the beneficiaries are the veteran employees of Yukos who were intended to benefit from the Mezzanine Amount under the Program.

• Accordingly, since the beneficiary class (*i.e.*, the employees) is open, there is no scope for the application of the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier*.

481.

In his First Opinion, Mr. Green interprets the VP Trust in some detail. He considers in particular the issue as to whether the veteran employees of Yukos could be said to be the beneficiaries of the trust. He criticizes Mr. Mann's analysis of this question in the following terms:

59. (1) Mr Mann was undoubtedly disadvantaged by the limited documentary material on the basis of which he appears to have been advising. But even on the basis of the documentation which he did have (the Trust and the Voting Committee Regulations), I have to say that I find the lack of analysis surprising.

(2) So far as I can see, Mr Mann's analysis in support of what for him is clearly the critical proposition that Yukos "owns" the Mezzanine Amount consists only of the final two sentences of paragraph 12 of his Opinion, on the basis of which he states his conclusion at paragraph 13 of his Opinion.

60. I too am disadvantaged by not having the Guidelines or any other internal Yukos documentation relating to the terms and implementation of the Program. However, in my opinion based on the material that I do have (i.e. the provisions of the Trust referred to at paragraph 16 above as corroborated by the provisions of the Agency Agreement and the other documentation referred to at paragraphs 17 to 19 above)-

(1) An interpretation which recognizes that the Mezzanine Amount was intended under the Trust to be held for the benefit of employees under the Program (and not other persons), is bound to be preferred to

(2) An interpretation under which the employees are not entitled under the Trust to benefit from the Mezzanine Amount at all, Yukos being entitled under the Trust to deal with the Mezzanine Amount entirely as it sees fit (which is Mr Mann's unsupported interpretation).

482.

Mr. Green then delivers his own analysis. He opines:

87. There are three main analyses of the beneficial interest in the Mezzanine Amount: two which I regard as serious contenders, and a third which is suggested by Mr Mann in his Opinion. Each of these analyses is potentially capable of being deployed in relation to any Jersey proper law employment benefit arrangement, whether or not the assets in question are limited to a fractional share of the property comprised within the trust. However, in the present case, such analyses are only relevant to the Mezzanine Amount, since YUL has retained to itself all interest in the fruits of the Yukos Shares with the exception of the Mezzanine Amount. It is only the Mezzanine Amount which has been settled for the benefit of employees within the contemplation of the Program in the present case.

88. The three analyses are as follows:

(1) The Mezzanine Amount is held on trusts of which the beneficiaries are the employees of Yukos falling within the ambit of the Program, with such beneficiaries' interests under the Trust reflecting those provided for in respect of them under the rules of the Program (the Guidelines). Under this analysis, whilst the employees may or may not have had parallel contractual rights as against Yukos as regards the provision of such benefits, such employees will be beneficiaries of a trust established to provide for such benefits and have received enforceable rights through that medium at least.

(2) Whilst the employees under the Program were the intended beneficiaries, nevertheless the terms of the Trust suggest that the RSP rather than such employees was the only party intended to have enforcement rights directly as against Chiltern. The trust of the Mezzanine Amount would be a valid purpose trust (a trust for the provision of monies for funding the Program), but its validity would depend on the RSP being the "enforcer" of such trust under Articles 12 and 13 of the Trusts (Jersey) Law 1984.

(3) The Mezzanine Amount is held on trust for Yukos, so that Yukos is intended to be free to call for the Mezzanine Amount to be paid over to it, for application by it (Yukos) for any purpose in complete disregard of the interests of the employees under the Program.

89. Of these three analyses, I believe that the first would be the preferred approach of the Royal Court.

[...]

91. This construction (and this construction alone) gives proper weight to the fact that it is the participants in the Program who are ultimately intended to benefit from the Mezzanine Amount, and that the RSP (as is made very clear by the terms of the Agency Agreement) is a mere conduit for the payment of proceeds from the sale of the Yukos Shares directly into US$ denominated bank accounts of such employees.

[emphasis added]

483.

Mr. Green adds that:

108. [...] There is no serious support in the Agency Agreement for the proposition that Yukos is intended to be absolute beneficial owner of the Mezzanine Amount.

484.

Mr. Green concludes at paragraph 115 that:

(1) YUL's establishment of the Trust as a means of making provision for employees of Yukos is coherent, in a way in which

(2) YUL's establishment of the Trust for the purpose of gifting to Yukos (part of) the proceeds of sale of its (Yukos's) own shares is not.

485.

The Tribunal finds Mr. Green's interpretation of the VP Trust more persuasive than Mr. Mann's and adopts it.

486.

Furthermore, the Tribunal does not accept Mr. Mann's later theory, presented in his Second Opinion, that the Mezzanine Amount was never settled into an enforceable trust. Rather, the Tribunal accepts Mr. Green's opinion that the VP Trust was completely and effectively constituted since YUL, being the owner of present property (the Yukos Shares), was able to assign such present property to a trustee (Chiltern) to hold the same on what are otherwise conceptually certain trusts.

487.

In any event, the Tribunal is satisfied that Article 8(a) of the Trusts (Jersey) Law 1984 allows "any property" to be placed in a trust, including "contingent" or "future" property. This is provided for expressly by the definition of "property" in Article 1(i) thereof. Thus, to the extent that the Mezzanine Amount is to be considered separate "property" distinct from the Yukos Shares—a proposition which was not substantiated by Respondent—the Tribunal finds that the Mezzanine Amount could be validly settled into trust under the definition of property given in the statute.

**(iv) Injection of Foreign Capital as a Requirement for a qualifying "Investment" under Article 1(6) of the Treaty**
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

488.

The Tribunal cannot accept Respondent's argument that an "Investment," to qualify under the ECT, requires an injection of foreign capital. Indeed, as already explained above, the definition of investment in Article 1(6) of the ECT does not include any additional requirement with regard to the origin of capital or the necessity of an injection of foreign capital. Specifically, paragraph 3 of the ECT Understandings, relating to Article 1(6) of the ECT, is of no assistance to Respondent, as it refers to the "control" facet of Article 1(6), not "ownership." The Tribunal refers, again, to the reasoning of the tribunal in the *Saluka* Award: "the predominant factor which must guide the Tribunal's exercise of its functions is the terms in which the parties to the Treaty now in question have agreed to establish the Tribunal's jurisdiction." The Tribunal cannot in effect impose upon the parties a definition of "Investment" other than that which the parties to the ECT, including Respondent, have agreed.

489.

Respondent in its written pleadings argued that the ECT is a treaty whose purpose is to promote foreign investment in the energy sector. The Introduction to the ECT prepared by the Energy Charter Secretariat provides, under the heading, "Investment," that "[t]he Treaty ensures the protection of foreign energy investments... By accepting the Treaty, a state takes on the obligation to extend national treatment, or most-favoured nation treatment (whichever is more favourable), to nationals and legal entities of other Signatory states who have invested in its energy sector."128 Various provisions of the Treaty, such as those of Article 9, which speak of investments in the areas of other Contracting Parties, particularly those with economies in transition, and Article 10, which speaks of each Contracting Party encouraging "Investors of other Contracting Parties to make Investments in its Area," show that the Treaty was written in contemplation of international investment, notably of investment by investors of developed States in economies in transition. It was not written in contemplation of investments by Russian nationals resident in Russia of capital generated in Russia. (At the same time, as the Tribunal has just pointed out,129 Claimant has referred to statements of President Putin welcoming the repatriation of capital controlled by Russians which has been placed abroad.)

Energy Charter Secretariat, *The Energy Charter Treaty and Related Documents: A Legal Framework for International Energy Cooperation* (2004), p. 14.

*See supra*, para. 463.

490.

As the Tribunal noted earlier, these conflicting contentions of the Parties go to the heart of the present dispute. The Tribunal accepts that the ECT is directed towards the promotion of foreign investment, especially of investment by Western sources in the energy resources of the Russian Federation and other successor States of the USSR. The Treaty is meant, as specified in the Secretariat's Introduction, to ensure "the protection of foreign energy investments." If the States that took part in the drafting of the ECT had been asked in the course of that process whether the ECT was designed to protect—and should be interpreted and applied to protect—investments in a Contracting State by nationals of that same Contracting State whose capital derived from the energy resources of that State, it may well be that the answer would have been in the negative, not only from the representatives of the Russian Federation but from the generality of the delegates. The ultimate source of the investments at issue in the instant cases may be Russian. The fortunes of the "oligarchs"—a term constantly employed in the pleadings of Respondent which the Tribunal for its part repeats without pejorative intent—may derive from investments by Russians in Russian resources.

491.

But, as the Tribunal noted earlier,130 the Tribunal is bound to interpret the terms of the ECT not as they might have been written so as exclusively to apply to foreign investment but as they were actually written. They are more comprehensively and neutrally cast. Specifically, Article 1(6) provides that, "'Investment' means every kind of asset, owned or controlled directly or indirectly by an Investor...." Article 1(7) provides that "Investor" means:

(a) with respect to a Contracting Party:

[...]

(ii) a company or other organization organized in accordance with the law applicable in that Contracting Party;

Claimant is organized "in accordance with the law applicable" in the Republic of Cyprus and owns shares of Yukos. Thus, Claimant owns an "Investment" protected by the ECT and the Tribunal so finds. The Tribunal is not entitled, by the terms of the ECT, to find otherwise.131

*See supra*, para. 413.

The Tribunal also notes that the Secretariat's Introduction to the Treaty was "included for convenience and must not be read as part of any official document or as an interpretation of any provisions therein." Energy Charter Secretariat, *The Energy Charter Treaty and Related Documents: A Legal Framework for International Energy Cooperation* (2004), p. 11 (para. 2 of "Explanatory Note").

492.

The Tribunal is well aware of Respondent's argument that Claimant in this arbitration has "unclean hands" and that Claimant's corporate personality should be disregarded because it is an instrumentality of a "criminal enterprise." The Tribunal recalls that it addressed these issues in its Procedural Orders Nos. 2 and 3 on 8 September and 31 October 2006. Specifically, the Tribunal then decided to defer consideration of Respondent's arguments concerning the "unclean hands" of Claimant or Claimant being an instrumentality of a "criminal enterprise" to any merits phase of this arbitration. Accordingly, by finding, as it does, that Claimant qualifies as an Investor owning or controlling an Investment for the purposes of Articles 1(7) and (6) of the ECT, the Tribunal does not dispose of the issues argued by Respondent concerning the "unclean hands" of Claimant and Claimant being an instrumentality of a "criminal enterprise," which it will address during any merits phase of this arbitration.

**C. ARE THE CLAIMS BARRED BY THE "DENIAL-OF-BENEFITS" PROVISION(ARTICLE 17) OF THE ECT?**
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

**1. Introduction**
-------------------

493.

Having concluded, in the previous chapter, that Claimant is a protected Investor with an Investment under the ECT, the Tribunal now turns to Respondent's argument that the benefits of Part III of the Treaty have been denied to Claimant by operation of Article 17 of the ECT.

494.

Part III of the ECT comprises the Treaty's substantive articles on "Investment Promotion and Protection." Most notably they prescribe, in Article 10, the standards of treatment, "the conditions," that each Contracting Party shall accord to "Investors of other Contracting Parties to make Investments in its Area." "Such conditions shall include a commitment to accord at all times to Investments of Investors of other Contracting Parties fair and equitable treatment... constant protection and security...," managerial control and observance of "any obligations" a Contracting Party has entered into with an Investor as well other treatment no less favorable than that required by international law. Article 13 provides that Investments shall not be nationalized or expropriated except under prescribed conditions.

495.

Article 17 of the ECT, the final article of Part III, provides for "Non-Application of Part III in Certain Circumstances." It specifies that:

Each Contracting Party reserves the right to deny the advantages of this Part to:

(1) a legal entity if citizens or nationals of a third state own or control such entity and if that entity has no substantial business activities in the Area of the Contracting Party in which it is organized...

496.

The foregoing "denial-of-benefits" clause has been a focus of conflicting arguments of the Parties. The Tribunal summarizes and evaluates those arguments in the sections that follow.

497.

However, insofar as those arguments are deemed to address the question of whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to pass upon the merits of the claims of Claimant, they are not on point. That is because Article 17 specifies—as does the title of that Article—that it concerns denial of the advantages of "this Part," *i.e.*, Part III of the ECT. Provision for dispute settlement under the ECT is not found in "this Part" but in Part V of the Treaty. Whether or not Claimant is entitled to the advantages of Part III is a question not of jurisdiction but of the merits. Since Article 17 relates not to the ECT as a whole, or to Part V, but exclusively to Part III, its interpretation for that reason cannot determine whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to entertain the claims of Claimant.

498.

The holding of the tribunal in *Plama v. Bulgaria* is on point:

Article 26 provides a procedural remedy for a covered investor's claims; and it is not physically or juridically part of the ECT's substantive advantages enjoyed by that investor under Part III. [...] This limited exclusion from Part III for a covered investor, dependent on certain specific criteria, requires a procedure to resolve a dispute as to whether that exclusion applies in any particular case; and the object and purpose of the ECT, in the Tribunal's view, clearly requires Article 26 to be unaffected by the operation of Article 17(1).132

*Plama Consortium Limited v. Republic of Bulgaria*, ICSID Case No. ARB/03/24, Decision on Jurisdiction of 8 February 2005, (2005) 20:1 *ICSID Review* 262, para. 148.

499.

This Tribunal finds the reasoning of the *Plama* tribunal on this point convincing and adopts it. At the same time, the Tribunal takes note of the fact that the Parties have treated the application of Article 17 as a question of admissibility, not jurisdiction,133 on which they differ. Accordingly, the Tribunal will pass upon the arguments of the Parties and determine the issue of the application of Article 17 definitively in this phase of the arbitration.

*See* First Memorial, Section III.C; Counter-Memorial, Section VII.C; Second Memorial, Section XIV; Rejoinder, Section IV.B.

500.

First, in Section 2, the Tribunal addresses the general issue of whether there is a notification requirement in Article 17 and whether Respondent satisfied any such requirement. Then, in Section 3, the Tribunal considers whether the substantive conditions for the application of Article 17(1) have been met.

**2. Notification Requirement**
-------------------------------

**a) Parties' Submissions**
---------------------------

501.

Respondent maintains in this phase of the arbitration that, even if it has any obligations towards Claimant under the ECT (which Respondent contests) it is entitled to deny the advantages of them to Claimant by reason of Article 17(1), and that it has done so. Respondent recalls that the terms of Article 17 derive from the "denial-of-benefits" clauses of bilateral investment treaties of the United States of America. While some but not all of these clauses require prior consultation and notification before invocation, as does NAFTA, Respondent notes that:

[N]o such notification and consultation requirement or other formal requirements are included in Article 17 of the Treaty. Thus, a company that is owned or controlled by nationals of a third State, and *a fortiori* by nationals of the host State, does not enjoy any benefits under Part III of the Treaty if it lacks substantial business activities in the Contracting Party in which it is organized.134

First Memorial, para. 124.

502.

In order to benefit from Treaty protections, Respondent contends, a company that comes within the scope of Article 17 must obtain a commitment from the host State that it will be treated as a protected investor. No such commitments have been obtained. On the contrary, Russia has, contemporaneously with negotiation of the ECT, ratified and proclaimed the P&C Agreement, which stipulates that companies having only a registered office in a State Party are not considered companies of that State unless "its operations possess a real and continuous link" with the latter's economy. The Russian Federation was not and is not in a position to know when, if ever, an investment is to be made within its territory or if a controlling investor even exists outside Russia, says Respondent, adding: "This is patently so where as here the controlling Russian oligarchs have employed dozens if not hundreds of offshore tax haven companies and ever shifting structures specifically designed to disguise ownership and control, evade taxes and launder money."135

*Ibid.* at para. 128.

503.

Respondent concludes: "For all the above reasons, Article 17(1) of the Treaty denies, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement has denied, and the Russian Federation hereby denies any and all benefits of Part III of the Treaty to the Russian oligarchs themselves, and to each and every one of their offshore shell companies and structures."136

*Ibid.* at para. 128.

504.

Claimant replies that Article 17 specifies that each Contracting Party "reserves the right to deny the advantages" of Part III. Thus the "right to deny" must be exercised "but until such time as this right has been effectively exercised," the investor benefits from the protection of Part III of the Treaty. Claimant disputes the reliance of the Russian Federation on the P&C Agreement, "a wholly irrelevant instrument in this arbitration."137 It maintains that the purported denial of benefits by the Russian Federation quoted in the foregoing paragraph—which is defective, Claimant says, because it does not expressly identify the particular Claimant companies (but refers just to "Russian oligarchs" and "offshore shell companies")—rather demonstrates Respondent's recognition that Article 17 requires an exercise of the reserved right. The reason for that exercise is to ensure legal certainty for investors in the ECT area. It quotes the Expert Opinion of Professor James Crawford:

To place on an individual investor the task of obtaining express assurance as to the extension of advantages would change the ECT from a general framework for investment in the energy sector to an invitation to establish, case-by-case, bilateral relations between investors and the host State. This was plainly not the intention.138

Counter-Memorial, para. 281.

*Ibid.* at para. 284 (citing para. 118 of the Expert Opinion).

505.

Claimant relies also on the jurisdictional holding of the arbitral tribunal in the case of *Plama v. Bulgaria:*

In the Tribunal's view, the existence of a "right" is distinct from the exercise of that right. [...] [A] Contracting Party has a right under Article 17(1) ECT to deny a covered investor the advantages of Part III; but it is not required to exercise that right; and it may never do so. The language of Article 17(1) is unambiguous; and that meaning is consistent with the different state practices of the ECT's Contracting States under different bilateral investment treaties: certain of them applying a generous approach to legal entities incorporated in a state with no significant business presence there (such as the Netherlands) and certain others applying a more restrictive approach (such as the USA). The ECT is a multilateral treaty with Article 17(1) drafted in permissive terms, not surprisingly, in order to accommodate these different state practices....139

*Ibid*. at para. 285 (citing para. 155 of the *Plama* decision).

506.

Moreover:

[A] putative covered investor has legitimate expectations of such advantages until that right's exercise. A putative investor therefore requires reasonable notice before making any investment in the host state whether or not that host state has exercised its right under Article 17(1) ECT. [...] [T]he object and purpose of the ECT suggest that the right's exercise should not have retrospective effect.140

*Ibid.* at para. 286 (citing paras. 161-162 of the *Plama* decision).

507.

Respondent counters that the ECT and P&C Agreement, contrary to Claimant's contentions, are not independent of each other, but cover much of the same ground. The P&C Agreement, upon its ratification, was published in the Russian Federation's Official Gazette and the official gazettes of the EU Member States. Investors must be deemed to be on notice of it, argues Respondent. In Article 30(h), the P&C Agreement denies benefits to companies incorporated in an EU Member State that do not have their principal place of business or central administration in such State and whose operations do not "possess a real and continuous link with the economy" of one of the EU Member States.

508.

Respondent also maintains that the *Plama* case is "weak authority with respect to its treatment of denial of benefits clauses" and "is suspect in its reasoning."141 It argues that:

The *Plama* standard, if accepted, would also impose an impossible standard for States, particularly for States in transition to a free market economy. The *Plama* standard converts something that the investor knows with certainty, whether it has substantial business in the State of incorporation and whether it is owned or controlled by third or host State nationals, into a burden to make such a determination with respect to a potential investor that a host State cannot know or determine.142

Second Memorial, paras. 384, 386.

*Ibid*. at para. 387.

509.

Respondent concludes:

At bottom, this is a domestic dispute involving enforcement of Russian taxes. [...] Accepting the Russian Federation's interpretation of Article 17(1) and of the interrelationship between Article 17(1) and Article 30(h) of the EU-Russia Partnership Agreement would constitute a principled basis, supported by the language of the two treaties, for distinguishing essentially domestic disputes from disputes involving genuine investors of Contracting Parties into the Russian Federation.143

*Ibid*. at para. 388.

510.

Claimant contends that the reserved right to deny under Article 17(1) must be exercised. Article 17(1) could have been otherwise drafted, as is Article VI of the ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services, to state that the advantages of Part III "shall be denied" to "a juridical person owned or controlled by persons of a non-Member State constituted under the laws of a Member State, but not engaged in substantive business operations in the territory of Member States." But the drafters of the ECT, submits Claimant, deliberately chose to provide for a reserved, optional right in Article 17(1), a right that must be exercised to take effect, and only prospectively. Russia's reliance on the P&C Agreement is unavailing, argues Claimant, because it defines a "Community company" or a "Russian company" for the purpose of that Agreement itself ("for the purpose of this Agreement"); the ECT makes no reference to that Agreement while it does refer to other "related instruments."

511.

Finally, at the stage of oral argument, the above contentions were canvassed anew by both Parties.

**b) Tribunal's Decision**
--------------------------

512.

In the view of the Tribunal, the position of Claimant on the interpretation and application of Article 17(1) to the instant case is more persuasive than that of Respondent. Article 17(1) does not deny *simpliciter* the advantages of Part III of the ECT—as it easily could have been worded to do—to a legal entity if the citizens or nationals of a third State own or control such entity and if that entity has no substantial business in the Contracting Party in which it is organized. It rather "reserves the right" of each Contracting Party to deny the advantages of that Part to such an entity. This imports that, to effect denial, the Contracting Party must exercise the right. Has the Russian Federation done so, either by concluding the P&C Agreement with the EU or by the passage in its pleading quoted at the end of paragraph 503 above? Not in the Tribunal's view.

513.

The P&C Agreement makes no reference to the ECT and the ECT makes no reference to it. They cover some common ground, and the P&C Agreement does require that benefiting companies have their principal place of business in and possess a real and continuous link with the economy of an EU State. But the lack of any reference to the ECT in the P&C Agreement and the lack of any reference to the P&C Agreement in the ECT defeats reliance upon Article 30(h) of the P&C Agreement as constituting the required exercise of a right under Article 17(1) of the ECT.

514.

In any event, if the passage in Respondent's First Memorial quoted above in paragraph 503 is construed as an exercise of the reserved right of denial, it can only be prospective in effect from the date of that Memorial. To treat denial as retrospective would, in the light of the ECT's "Purpose," as set out in Article 2 of the Treaty ("The Treaty establishes a legal framework in order to promote long-term cooperation in the energy field...") be incompatible "with the objectives and principles of the Charter." Paramount among those objectives and principles is "Promotion, Protection and Treatment of Investments" as specified by the terms of Article 10 of the Treaty. Retrospective application of a denial of rights would be inconsistent with such promotion and protection and constitute treatment at odds with those terms.

515.

In sum, the Tribunal finds, on the basis of the evidence before it, that Respondent has not denied and cannot now be heard to deny, and will not be able to deny to Claimant in any merits phase of these proceedings, the advantages and the benefits of Part III of the ECT on the basis of Article 17.

**3. Substantive Conditions**
-----------------------------

516.

It is convenient here to revisit the text of Article 17(1), which specifies that:

Each Contracting Party reserves the right to deny the advantages of this Part to:

(1) a legal entity if citizens or nationals of a third state own or control such entity and if that entity has no substantial business activities in the Area of the Contracting Party in which it is organized [...]

[emphasis added]

It is apparent from the wording of Article 17(1) that two additional cumulative substantive conditions must be met before the "denial-of-benefits" clause can be exercised in respect of any particular legal entity. First, such legal entity must be owned or controlled by citizens or nationals of a third State; second, the legal entity must have no substantial business activities in the place in which it is organized.

517.

In view of the Tribunal's conclusion, explained in the previous section, that Respondent cannot invoke Article 17(1) due to its failure to give notice to Claimant that it was doing so, there is no need, in principle, to address Respondent's submissions that these substantive conditions for the application of Article 17(1) have been satisfied. However, since the Tribunal was briefed extensively on the issues of ownership and control, and on the issue of whether Russia is a "third state" for purposes of Article 17(1), the Tribunal has decided to set out its analysis and conclusions in respect of these issues. The Tribunal also addresses in this section Respondent's alternative contention that Claimant is owned and/or controlled by Israeli nationals, it being undisputed that Israel is a "third state" for purposes of Article 17(1). Since Claimant has conceded that it conducts no substantial business activities in Cyprus, the Tribunal does not need to address that issue.

**a) Ownership and Control of Claimant**
----------------------------------------

**(i) Factual Background**
--------------------------

518.

The Tribunal refers to the factual and documentary background set out above at paragraph 420.

**(ii) Parties' Submissions**
-----------------------------

519.

Respondent submits that Claimant is no more than an instrumentality of the "Russian oligarchs," owned and controlled by them through YUL, GML and the Guernsey Trusts. In order to reach this conclusion, Respondent submits that the VP Trust is essentially a sham.

520.

Claimant's position is that the VP Trust is perfectly valid and legitimate, with the result that Chiltern (the Custodian Trustee) owns the VPL Shares (*i.e.*, owns Claimant), pursuant to Clause 3 of the VP Trust, and controls VPL (*i.e.*, controls Claimant), pursuant to Clause 5(2) of the VP Trust. Clause 5(2) expressly provides that Chiltern "shall have discretion as to the exercise of voting rights attaching to the Cypriot Shares [*i.e.*, the VPL Shares]." Claimant notes further that, pursuant to Clause 6(5) of the VP Trust, Chiltern or any of its officers or employees may act as director or other officer or employee of VPL.

521.

Accordingly, Claimant submits that, because both ownership and control of Claimant is vested with Chiltern, a company incorporated in Jersey, and because the UK has confirmed that its ratification of the ECT covers the Bailiwick of Jersey, ownership and control of Claimant is vested with a national of a Contracting Party. As a result, Claimant argues, Article 17 cannot apply.

522.

In response, relying on the expert opinions of Mr. Mann, Respondent submits that, notwithstanding the formal structure of the VP Trust, Chiltern does not have beneficial ownership and control of the VPL Shares. Mr. Mann opines that YUL (and Yukos, if necessary) can invoke the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier* to terminate the trust and cause the VPL Shares to be retransferred to them.

523.

In paragraph 18 of his First Opinion, Mr. Mann states:

(3) YUL and YUKOS can jointly instruct Chiltern to re-transfer the Cypriot shares. The necessity for a joint instruction is not on account of joint beneficial ownership (it is obvious that YUL is nominally sole beneficial owner of these shares) but because it is a reasonable inference that YUKOS has some arrangements with YUL which, if these two entities are not one and the same for all practical purposes, could enable YUKOS to obstruct re-transfer at any time without its consent and before termination.

[emphasis added]

524.

As set out in the previous chapter of this Interim Award,144 Mr. Green, Claimant's expert, disagrees with Mr. Mann's analysis of the VP Trust. Mr. Green also disagrees with Mr. Mann that the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier* finds application in the circumstances of this case.

*See* paras. 111-118, 209-214, 426, 438, 446-460, 479-486.

525.

Mr. Green sets out, in his First Opinion, the reasons for his conclusion:

• There is an implied agreement in the VP Trust not to exercise *Saunders v. Vautier* rights.

• The rule in *Saunders v. Vautier* is inapplicable in the context of the employee benefit program.

• The trustee's rights of indemnity take priority over any other equitable interest in the VPL Shares.

• In any event, *Saunders v. Vautier* rights do not confer a right of present "ownership" or "control" if they are not actually exercised by the beneficiaries.

526.

Mr. Mann devotes a substantial part of his Second Opinion to explain that these three factors, in his view, do not rule out the application of the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier* to this case. He concludes that Mr. Green's opinion that Chiltern owns and controls the VPL Shares is unsound.

527.

In his Second Opinion, Mr. Green reaffirms his position that the rule in *Saunders v. Vautier* cannot be invoked in the circumstances of this case and that, in any event, the rule has not been invoked by any beneficiary who may be entitled to do so. As a result, Mr. Green confirms his conclusion that "the mere existence of such principle does not and cannot displace the proposition that Chiltern 'owns' and 'controls' the VPL Shares."

528.

Respondent submits a further argument to support its proposition that Chiltern does not control Claimant:

276. In these very particular circumstances, where Claimant is a mere nominee deprived of any power over its assets whatsoever, it does not matter who controls Claimant itself. What matters is who beneficially owns and controls the sole assets nominally held by Claimant.

277. Claimant admits as much:

*"Chiltern Trust exercises control on the shares of Yukos until completion of the Veteran Trust. Both the ownership and control of the Claimant is thus vested with Chiltern Trust, a company incorporated in Jersey."*

Thus Claimant acknowledges that whoever controls the Yukos shares held by Claimant controls, by implication, Claimant itself.

[emphasis added]

529.

Respondent submits that because YUL and Yukos (through the Voting Committee) exercise control over the Yukos Shares held by Claimant, and because the relevant question for control of Claimant, as admitted by Claimant itself, is control over the Yukos Shares, it is the "Russian oligarchs," through YUL and Yukos, who control Claimant.

530.
